segments.text: This is Professor Larry Hoover of Sam Houston State University, November 15, 1984.
This interview concerns crowd control and changes in crowd control during the 1960s.
Dr. Hoover, could you please give me your background, such as where you were born and when schools attended, and how you made your way to Sam Houston State University?
I was born in 1945 and raised in the state of Michigan.
I entered college at Michigan State University, majoring in what was then called
police administration and public safety.
Since that time, all these programs have modified the terminology to reflect criminal justice as the title of the degree.
Intending to go to law school at the University of Michigan, completed my degree in police science administration and was out of money.
So I went to work for the Lansing, Michigan Police Department.
Lansing, Michigan is the city of
a metropolitan area of about 200,000, very much like Austin, Texas.
It's the capital city of the state.
It has a large university there.
Unlike Austin, there's a fair amount of heavy industry in that area, the automobile industry.
Went on to police department, given my major, went on to police department and intended to stay about six months, save up money, and then go on to law school.
One thing led to another and ended up staying in police work.
Went back out to Michigan State, took a master's degree in what was then called criminal justice, then received a PhD in higher educational administration.
Spent approximately four years on the Lansing Police Department in several capacities, primarily in the police patrol division, however.
and left there for the Michigan Law Enforcement Officers Training Council.
It's a state organization which controls, coordinates police training in that state.
There are analogous organizations in every state now, including Texas.

Spent a year and a half there, and then went on the faculty at Michigan State University for five years, and left there in 1977, came to Sam Houston State University, where I'm now a professor of criminal justice here.
What riots have you been in and how were you involved?
I was on the patrol officer in the Lansing Michigan Police Department between 1967 and 1971.
In that time period we experienced two distinct kinds of disturbances.
One were the
Riots, I guess if we could call them that, in the black neighborhoods, the black ghetto riots of the late 60s, which did occur in Lansing as well as other cities.
Of course, the riots in Detroit received national attention when army units had to be called in to finally
restore order in Detroit.
Forty-some people died in the disturbances in Detroit, but virtually every other city in Michigan at that time experienced similar disturbances, although on, obviously, a smaller scale.
A second kind of disturbance were the demonstrations with regard to the United States' involvement in the Vietnam War.
With a very large university, Michigan State University, immediately adjacent to the city of Lansing, we experienced several

uh... disturbances demonstrations which became disturbances and uh... i participated in i suppose three or four of those in terms of trying to affect crowd control the ghetto riots are a little hard more difficult to to to quantify uh... in lansing we did not experience a a uh...
a riot which had a given time frame to place around it.
It wasn't as if we had three days of looting and burning, but rather throughout the summer of 1968 and summer of 1969, we experienced periodic disturbances.
And I suppose I ended up in riot gear and assigned to that area 20 times during those two summers.
OK.
How did you as a policeman feel going into a riot or potential riot situation?
Afraid.
Afraid.
I think one of the things that is not well understood about confrontations between police and crowds, hostile crowds, demonstrators, is the amount of fear that the police have.
You see the police appear in riot gear with helmets and with batons, sidearms on their waist.
They come out in force, 50 or 60 officers, and the assumption is made that those individuals are calm, cool, collected, are perfectly confident of their own safety.
Whenever that's not the case, in fact, they're very much afraid.
One of the anomalies of attempting to control civil disturbances is the fact that a police officer is limited in the amount of force that he can use.

the fact that you have a gun with you is probably the greatest threat that you experience because the overwhelming fear is that the crowd will manage to isolate you, will either beat and kick you to death, which has occurred, or someone will grab your firearm, someone will grab your revolver and use it on you.
So the police, whenever they approach that kind of a situation, they're scared to death.
And they react appropriately.
And I think that's something we need to understand about the psychology of crowd control, is that in any textbook one looks at, articles about this issue,
that are entitled Psychology of Crowd Control, it's a one-way perspective.
It's written about the psychology of the crowd, not the psychology of the controlling agents.
And dealing with the psychology of the controlling agents and the fear that they have is every bit as important as dealing with the crowd.
I recall on an anecdotal basis, I can't resist noting,
that there was a massive march scheduled from the campus of Michigan State University to the State Capitol building in Lansing.
It's a distance probably of four miles, I would guess.
And of course, every law enforcement agency in the area were mobilized.
And consistent with policy at that time, one had a minimum number, as long as the demonstration was peaceful, one had a minimum number of officers on the street.
You tried to keep
a very low profile so that you didn't beget confrontation, so it did not appear as though you were challenging the crowd's right to assemble, freedom of speech.
And so a few officers were assigned for traffic control to escort them down the main street of town, similar to Congress Avenue over in Austin, if you're familiar with that.
What year was this?
Best of my recollection, this would have been 1968, part of the series of demonstrations occurring around the country in conjunction with the Democratic National Convention and so forth.
They had a group of us, probably 50, 60 officers.
We were assembled in the basement of City Hall.
If we were needed, if the crowd became unruly, then they would muster us.
We would have been mustered out to try to effect control.
And an officer next to me had a reasonable sense of humor.
turned and, I have to add, we just told that the estimated size of the crowd was 20,000.
And the officer next to me turned and said, well, there's altogether maybe 100 of us.
Given 20,000 of them, that means we're outnumbered 201.
I just wanted to tell you, though, that you're outnumbered 400 to 1 because I'm going to turn and run like hell.
And it's that story.
We laughed about it, but it was kind of laughing about it that was done in a sort of a, oh, I'm not quite sure what the right term is, but there was a certain amount of,
real fear that went, we were laughing at death staring in the face, and it really wasn't all that humorous.
Yes, definitely.
Did the feeling of placement change over the sixties, or was it pretty much the same?
Well, I think we got, as we gained experience with it, we became more confident, and more competent and confident, both, and one is certainly as important as the other, related to one another.

recognized that most police officers right now, in 1984, had never experienced an unruly crowd of any size, and never had to affect crowd control where they were stirring it up, a large demonstration.
In American society, these events occur sporadically enough, even in times of, relatively speaking, civil unrest.
They're still rare enough that most officers have not had experience in dealing with them.
Most departments have not had experience in dealing with them.
Consequently, you make all the classic mistakes those first couple times around.
Generally speaking, by the time you've gained experience, it's all over with.
The issue has passed.
It's been the history since, certainly in the last 20 years at least.
Whatever the issue has been has become moot, and the opportunity to pass that experience along does not exist.
Now, in terms of specific tactical changes, I would say no.
The tactics that were used were probably the same throughout.
The difference was in terms of the way those tactics were employed, the confidence with which we approached the scenes, how competent we were.
We knew the right things to do.
That is the textbook response from the outset.
The point was that the psychology, the fear, the confusion,
that ensued.
In some cases, lack of equipment, particularly in the very early times, begets serious problems.
Officers, for example, officers are instructed not to speak to anyone in a crowd.
That sometimes, the temptation becomes overwhelming, someone's yelling profanities in your face to

give them a word back and uh it takes a couple times to to learn i suppose that that's not going to get you anywhere it's not going to give you be a source of any self-satisfaction to you and when those lessons are learned you do tend to become better at crowd control you've already i know you've already touched on it but what was the the core psychology of the police how did
they feel towards each other, how they feel as a group when they went into a situation.

Well, one of the interesting points that I would make is that the police are placed in a role, not only in terms of crowd control, riot, civil disturbances, but in terms of their daily operating environment, are placed in a role of maintaining the status quo.
And as such, it doesn't matter how you feel about the particular cause.
It doesn't matter how you feel about the social situation in a black ghetto.
Your role is maintenance of order, and that's the mandate that you're given.
You hold up your right hand and swear that you're going to uphold the Constitution of the United States, a particular state, and the statutory law that pertains thereto.
One can be very sympathetic to the demonstrators.
One can be very sympathetic to the rioters.
But you're going to enforce the law.
And as such, one is caught in a position of, the academic term would be some cognitive dissonance.
Although you personally may have been sympathetic to the protest against the Vietnam War, you personally may have felt that we should get out of Vietnam.
Nevertheless, your job was to make sure that a demonstration with regard to that issue did not get out of hand.
That puts you in an inevitable conflict position.
Now what happens as a civil disturbance situation,
gains momentum as it progresses and the minutes go into hours and hours into days, there are sufficient transgressions by the other side, physical transgressions, assaults, profanities,
rocks hurled at you, efforts to, you know, efforts to injure you and your colleagues.
And you don't know them as uniforms.
You know them as people who have children after raising and everything else.

And you stand and I stand and look to my side and I see a good friend, Jim Harkin, who had three children, all under five, take a brick on the helmet and even with that helmet, knock him unconscious and suffered a serious concussion hauling him away from the ambulance.
It doesn't take you very long to get angry.
You may be sympathetic to the general cause, but you get angry at the people over there.
Because you are treated in a law enforcement role as if you're a non-human entity, as if you're a machine inside a uniform.
And that's resented.
You resent that.
And so you find officers who...
who are sympathetic to the cause, nevertheless striking out.
The problem of controlling the police, of keeping the nightsticks down, gets to be a very serious problem.
I'll give you a case in point from more recent past.
We had, in the past year, a march in Austin by the Ku Klux Klan.
Get it out yet?
The Ku Klux Klan.
We had several groups in Austin, as well as the general public, objecting strongly to that and were determined to harass the Klan on their march.
The Klan had a right to march, a right to assemble.
And the police have to protect the right of the Ku Klux Klan to assemble, whether they agree with them or not.
There was constant harassment of the Klan as they marched down the route in Austin.
And sometimes that gets very unpleasant.
Bags of feces were tossed, for example.
And some of it hits a Klan, and occasionally police officers walking beside a Klansman gets hit.
And the police officers reacted in a very predictable way.
They became angry at the people who were attempting to stop the Klan from marching.
Now, I assure you that the Austin Police Department, the caliber of officers on that Austin Police Department, are not sympathetic towards the KKK or their cause.
and are far more sympathetic, are very sympathetic to the ideological position of the crowd that's attempting to stop the march.
But they were cast into that role, an adversarial role, with the crowd, and a supportive role, in essence, with the KKK, since they were charged with protecting the KKK.
And as you know, towards the end of the march, while there was an incident in which
police lines, it was an effort to break police lines.
And officers attempting to effect an arrest of one individual started flailing some nightsticks, probably took
It looked bad on national television.
It looked like they were just wailing the devil out of the people.

In effect, if you take that, and I watched a slow-motion version of that that Frank Dyson had, showed the chief's administrative conference here a few months ago, and actually you're dealing with maybe three or four
swings with a nightstick that were not necessary.
I won't say probably not necessary.
Were not necessary to affect the arrest.
But the officers were involved in a one-on-one as a mob surrounding them, probably 20, 30 people.
You're dealing with three or four officers.

And again, the assumption is those officers are actually confident of their own safety, have no fear at all, and in fact, are scared to death that somebody's going to grab a gun or grab the nightstick and wail on them or whatever.
The police.
will inevitably come into conflict with a crowd that is attempting to make a political statement through civil disobedience.
No question about that.
This leads right into, how do you define a police riot?
What are the signs you can see that bring that down?
Well, we've probably only had
One incident, a police riot in the United States since the Second World War, and I don't know, I'm not familiar enough with history prior to that to know for sure.
And that was in 1968 at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
A police riot occurs whenever individual officers cannot be controlled by their supervisors.
And that's what happened in Chicago.
It became supervisory orders were, in effect, ignored on the street in Chicago.
And individual officers were effecting street justice, clubbing demonstrators, and so forth.
That's a fascinating incident, by the way, in terms of the full history of that.
And again, the police psychology surrounding that incident.
Few people are aware of the fact that deliberate efforts were made by some of the extremist groups.

And I hasten to add that the demonstrators in Chicago consisted of a real mix of people, which is part of the problem, from extremist groups who were determined to force violence, feeling that was a part of a strategy to effect political change, to curious onlookers.
Efforts were made to obtain home addresses of police officers.
Threats were made that while the officers were controlling the demonstrations, the extremist groups would, quote, get their families.
Families, generally the police banded together, although it was not an official city policy, the police banded together, and during those Tuesday, Wednesday nights,
whenever things were at their worst, had moved their families out of their homes.
Now one of the things that, the lesson there is when the police quit
cease to be bureaucrats, when the police are personally threatened, are no longer simply performing a bureaucratic role, but feel a personal threat, they're going to be very difficult to control.
And they're not going to play by the rules anymore.
And if somebody starts threatening your family, what you see is, even if the threat is not specific, even if your telephone's never rung at home,
Even if you have no direct evidence that that's going to occur, if there's talk of doing that, then police officers will react accordingly.
Will simply strike out against what they see as a symbolic assailants, which are the demonstrators on the street.
And that's what happened in Chicago.
When and to what extent did training on crowd psychology occur in the 60s?
When was it stepped up?
recognized, first of all, that police training was done only sporadically before 1968, 69.
As a point in fact, it was probably some of the problems of civil disturbances which beget political action that mandates police training.
in virtually every state, police officers are required by law to complete a certain minimum number of hours of basic training.
In addition to that, there's available advanced in-service training.

Those laws were passed by and large in 1969 through 1972 and were not entirely a product of the difficulties the police experienced in controlling civil disturbances, but that certainly was a contribution.
The fact that

that inadequate or inappropriate police action, often aggravated situations that aggravated civil disturbances rather than assisted in quelling them, was part of the impetus to get mandatory basic training laws for our police passed, part of the impetus for trying to recruit college-educated individuals in the police service, which is now very widespread.

So the training which was received, and I'm giving you a long-winded answer to your question, but it's important to recognize that the largest agencies generally had basic training and had had since the 1950s, at least basic training.
Relatively little, if any, in-service training was done.
So the police approached that whole era, 1965 through 1970, essentially untrained in crowd control.
Individual officers, at least, had not had specific training.
Now,

once disturbances started, why training programs were geared up very quickly and agencies would offer one-day seminars or would offer roll call training to officers in terms of behavior during crowd control situations and so forth.
Do you think this was an important change?
Did it really help?
No.
Primarily, what one must deal with in terms of police
The reason I say that is the tactics for crowd control were known despite the training, and the supervisory personnel were apprised and were aware of what tactics should be employed.
The difficulty was in dealing with the psychology of the officers, not in the officers not knowing what a wedge was or what the proper way to hold a nightstick was.
It was in the officers' psychological approach to aggressive crowds, and that was really the primary source of the difficulty.
Okay.
Which crowds were the easiest to handle and which type of crowds were the worst to handle?
The different, you know, the race and the war crowd, war demonstrators?
Well, the war demonstrators were probably easier to handle than the race riot situations, unquestionably were easier to handle than the race riot situations.
One of the things that goes unrecognized, and I, to the best of my knowledge,
Not one individual was killed by a police officer, a civilian police officer in this country, during the course of the war demonstrations.
And we often, we talk about police riots and police being out of control during that era and how terrible it was.
That's a bunch of bunk.
We did not have scores of people laying dead on the streets.
Compare that to some of the experiences that have occurred in Europe, some of the experiences which have occurred in Japan, for example, and they've had much worse experience.

So despite the lack of preparedness on the part of the American police, despite the lack of equipment, despite the fear that was engendered, the amount of alienation that at that time existed between the police and extremist war demonstrators,
People were not dying in the streets of the United States in 1967 to 1972.
The one incident where we had, of course, death occur was at Kent State with the Ohio National Guard.
And I'll reiterate a point I made earlier.
You were dealing with a group of people, National Guard, inexperienced and scared to death.
And you had, in essence, what we talk about, the agents of the state, the military firing upon helpless civilians.
In effect, what you had was a bunch of 18-year-olds shooting at a bunch of other 18-year-olds.
And there's a world of difference in terms of one's perception and view of that incident, depending upon what words are used, the semantics that are used to describe the incident.
I don't excuse the actions of that unit of the Ohio National Guard, but I certainly understand the actions in terms of the fear that they experienced.
And again, if you look at the videotapes of the situation, you say, oh my God, here they are armed with rifles, and you've got a bunch of college students.
How could they possibly feel threatened?
But they do feel threatened.
And unquestionably, what happens is a form of crowd psychology or mob psychology occurred within the rank of the National Guard whenever the first shot went off.
And as of yet, I don't believe it was ever established who fired the first shot or why.

For all we know, it could have been an accidental discharge of a gun, but once that first shot was fired, then a kind of crowd psychology overcame the guard, and of course a volley of shots were then fired.
But it's very important to note, first of all, even four people dying during that era with the amount of potential violence that could have occurred,

the number of bombings that were occurred, the number of ambushes that occurred against police officers where they were killed in ambush, and the fact that only four people in the country died in demonstrations is an outstanding record, and it's even more interesting to note that no one died at the hands of civilian police.
That's good.
I know when Martin Luther King was assassinated, several riots broke out.
What kind of impact do you think riots in other parts of the country have on potential riot situations?
Oh, without any question, it's a chain reaction event.
We would, in Lansing, which is 90 miles from Detroit, we would monitor the situation in Detroit on an hour-by-hour basis during those hot summer months in those years because we knew that the minute
disturbance broke out in Detroit, it was very likely that we would have disturbances occurring in Lansing.
Yes, there is very much a chain reaction that occurs in those kind of instances.
The ghetto riots have a wholly different character to them.
In the first place, one tends not to deal with aggregated mobs, with mobs collected, a lot of people in one place.
Rather, you deal with small groups of young males.
I don't recall ever seeing a group larger than 10, for example, in my experiences in trying to control disturbances in the Black Ghetto in Lansing.
And that was true in Detroit as well, maybe somewhat larger.
The groups never operated as unified mobs.

Rather, you'd get looting that would break out on a particular street, and it'd be a dozen people in one store and a dozen people in another store and so forth, rather than really a concerted movement.
Even in those situations, though, there was...
there was a certain understanding which existed about the level of force that was going to be used.
Undoubtedly, in certain cities in the Watts section of Los Angeles, in Detroit, in Newark, New Jersey,
The rioting degenerated, the reaction of the police degenerated such that there were instances of shooting to kill.
People died in all those cities.
In the majority of disturbances in the country, though, no one shot to kill.
We responded, I recall responding on a couple of instances.
A typical tactic on the part of black activists at that time
was to set an automobile on fire.
It was parked on a street.
Fire department would get called.
Fire department would respond.
During that era, the police naturally were called automatically to accompany the fire department.
In fact, as a point in fact, in many cities, police go automatically anyway for traffic control.
But in these instances, you would go in case there were problems.
And firemen would bail onto the truck.
You'd pull up in the patrol car and get out and look around.
And you'd hear shots go off.
Everybody dive for cover, take off.
You get on the police radio and call for backup and crouch down behind a car.
I never saw a bullet hole in a police car.
I never had a bullet crack on the pavement next to me.
They were shooting in the air.
It was a kind of situation where there was sort of a, at best I can call it a tacit understanding,
that we weren't going to be killed as long as we didn't shoot to kill back.
And that was generally done.
Now, I don't want to get Pollyannish about this.
People die.

And I don't want to exaggerate this, but in the majority of instances, the vast majority of instances, 99% of the instances, people could have died but didn't because it was an understanding on both sides you weren't going to kill.
OK.
You've already said a few of them, but what factors can change a crowd's mood to violence quickly?
Things the police can do, things their leader can do?
Yeah, one is always cautious in terms of crowd control.
It's term in the literature, trigger events.
One of the tactics in terms of crowd control is if police make a judgment that a crowd is going to get out of hand,
is to attempt to go in and arrest leaders, to make selective arrests.
You always try to avoid mass arrests if you can.
And that's done, the way that's done is to go in very quickly, grab somebody, drag them off, and pull back immediately again, not stay in immediate physical proximity of the crowd.
That tactic is...
is premised upon the notion that if you can remove sources of instigation, specific sources of instigation, you could probably keep a crowd under control.
In relatively few instances is a crowd destined to riot, or destined to become aggressive.
It usually takes either someone who's inciting the crowd, or an action on the police, or in some cases they get out of control over something that no one can control.
Some event occurs that finally incites the crowd to riot.
Police tactics include extreme restraint.
I mentioned previously, you don't even speak to someone in a crowd.
You try to keep a reasonable distance back so that the direct physical confrontation, physical contact does not occur.
In the early stages of a crowd, you operate with minimum show of force at the point whenever
whenever the line is being crossed and the crowd is being triggered into aggressive action, then you show up with massive force, intimidating force is the general tactic.
So in general what you do is have a small contingent, as few as three or four officers, who might be standing in the vicinity of the crowd, monitoring the crowd.
If something triggers the crowd or if it appears as though it's inevitable that they're going to become aggressive,
Then you have waiting a block away in a bus or in some other kind of public building or whatever, a large contingent of officers to move in very quickly.
And whenever you move in, you try to, there are certain rules of the road.
You give the crowd a route to escape.
It's like you don't trap a rattlesnake in the corner unless you want him to strike at you.
You don't trap a crow in the corner unless you want them to strike.
So you give them a chance to escape.
You try to subdivide the crowd.
You try to get into smaller and smaller groups as you disperse them to break that up, to sort of diffuse the mob psychology that occurs.
How did the demonstrators feel towards the police before the police had done anything?
And has that changed over the 60s, during the decade?
As more riots went on, as the police came, there was sudden hostility?
No, I would not say that there was extreme hostility at the outset of a demonstration, even over a period of time, even after there had been several demonstrations.
dealing with two really very different kinds of incidents, so we'll have to talk about each of them separately.
In the Vietnam protests, the Vietnam War demonstrations, the crowd largely regarded the police as part of the bigger game that was being played.
It was all a matter of gamesmanship.
As long as things were done within certain parameters, as long as somebody wasn't dragged off and being beaten, relatively speaking, peace would prevail at those demonstrations.
Now, if a brick is thrown, and a police officer gets hurt, and a police retaliate by clubbing someone, then the level of violence tends to get on an escalating spiral.
But I don't think the crowds in the Vietnam War protests approached the police intending to harm the police.
I don't think they approached the police with extreme hostility.
If anything, I suppose they regarded the police as sort of, and even among those who were totally taken up with the rhetoric at the time, as...
as dupes or lackeys of the ruling elite who really were not evil in their own right, but were just misled.
And so did not demonstrate any kind of hatred for the police.
It was interesting.
I'll describe one incident to you.
During one of the demonstrations out at Michigan State University,
There existed at Michigan State a commercial strip, a campus strip, like is common in so many campuses, bookstores and t-shirt shops and the like, restaurants.
And that evening, the city council in East Lansing, similar to College Station Bryan situation, the city council in East Lansing had considered a resolution
opposing the Vietnam War.
And I don't know what even action was taken.
But a large crowd had shown up with that.
Things got out of hand, got unruly.
A bunch of the college kids started rocking a fire chief's car, red fire car that was there.
And before they finished rocking it, they had turned it on its top.
And at that point, why, the whole area of police agencies were mobilized.
Of course, we had inter-jurisdictional compacts to assist one another.
Still do, of course, in those situations.
And the mob made the round down the front of that college strip and through bricks, stones, whatever, through the glass windows.
And so all the windows were broken out down this strip.
Now, interestingly, no looting occurred.
No one reached in and took so much as a t-shirt.
But they broke out the windows as an expression of protest, an expression of rage, I suppose.
We ended up showing up in the scene and crossed a large, divided avenue with a little boulevard, a grass boulevard in the middle.
On one side were all the college students.
That was the campus side.
We lined up in front of these stores, hypothetically protect the stores, just keep watching the situation.
Well, the hours drug on, and this happened to be in February, middle of the wintertime.
It was cold in Lansing, Michigan in February.
That night, the temperature was somewhere around zero.
And that probably kept the size of the crowd down and kept the mood cool.
In any case, someone over the net size I thought was a brilliant move, dreamed up a tactic.
They baited us over across the street, and I can't recall now how they did it.
whether they, as I recall, they drug a box of bricks and dumped them in a pile or something like that.
And so we were committed to removing any projectiles away.
And so a group of officers, probably 20, 30 officers, moved across the street in typical wedge formation to retrieve the bricks, to remove them so they wouldn't be thrown at the police.
Well, that movement brought them and immediately

underneath the student union building and the students were prepared up there they had drugged the fire hoses out at the situation where you have fire hoses right in the hallway they drug the fire hoses out when the police got underneath the windows the student union building they threw open the windows turned on the valves and just sprayed 30-40 officers down well at zero degrees you don't stay out there in soaking wet clothes so we had to take those all had to be retired but there were
Students just broke out laughing.
And to be honest with you, over in the police side, we broke out laughing as well.
There were incidences where it was almost a, that's part of the gamesmanship involved.
You weren't really going to hurt each other.
Although a flying brick is certainly going to do some damage.
But I don't think even those who threw the brick intended that they would kill a police officer by throwing that brick, or permanently maim a police officer by throwing that brick.
OK.
Moving on to politics, LBJ was quoted in 1964 saying this is a tough time to be a police officer.
Do you agree with this statement and why?
It definitely was a tough time to be a police officer.
I fully agree with Lyndon Johnson's statement in that regard.
The primary reason was not any immediate physical threat of policing the demonstrations or policing the ghetto riots, although that certainly was germane.
problem was the amount of public hostility against you.
I was just a recent graduate of Michigan State and had gone on the police department.
And one would go out there to demonstrations and be called every conceivable name one could imagine.
And this is going to sound almost humorous, but it hurts your feelings.
It's nice to say that one is insulated against that, that you separate the bureaucratic role from the personal role and all that, but you don't.
We all get caught up in our occupational roles and identify with that occupational role.
The amount of hostility, the amount of alienation, the outright hatred of the police in the black ghetto was very difficult to cope with.
One would show up and you were
Whether you wanted to be or not, you were perceived as the Gestapo, as an agent of a repressive and unjust state.
And no one likes to be in that role.
There wasn't anything I could personally do about the plight of blacks in the United States, then or now, in the sense of massive reform or leading massive reform.
Yet one was cast, and had then, and of course still have, a great deal of sympathy towards that situation.
But yet you're cast, and you pull up on a scene, and you're greeted with, well, it's the man.
It's the man.
Everybody shut up.
It's the man.
Who are you going to whip up on this time?
Those kind of comments.
And threats from crowds in those situations and so forth.
Of course, every call you responded to during that era, particularly during much of July and August up north, we were tense on.
Because if a crowd started to gather at all, you were very afraid it was going to turn into a civil disturbance very quickly, and frequently did.
And it was hard to maintain psychological balance in terms of, I'm doing the right thing.
I'm performing a needed role.
This is an honorable profession.

The college kids are screaming at you one time that you're supporting murder in Southeast Asia, and the black residents are screaming at you the next day that you're perpetuating poverty and exploitation.
That was the primary difficulty in being a policeman during that era.
What impact, if any, did Johnson's administration have on crowd control during the 60s?
have any legislation that would help support the placement on what you're just talking about?
To be honest with you, I don't recall any national legislation that was passed that was directly pertinent to crowd control.
Every state, well, first of all, we're fine.
We teach criminal law classes over here.
One of the things that our faculty do is
When we refer to any state, we refer to it as the sovereign state of.
So if we talk about the state of Texas, we talk about the sovereign state of Texas.
And one of the reasons we do that is to impress upon students the fact that in terms of criminal statutes, we deal with 50 different systems in this country.
Federal law has limited applicability towards criminal law enforcement.
As such, laws that were applicable towards crowd control
were state statutes, and all states have general statutes against rioting, insurrection, and so forth.
I just simply don't recall any federal legislation that had any impact out on the street level.
Do you remember any state changes while you were in the force that you saw, whether it was psychological or equipment?
The primary change, I don't recall any statutory changes that had any particular effect.
There were statutes passed generally at that time.
The only one I can remember are statutes passed about carrying gasoline away from gas stations and containers, which statutes were passed which forbid you from doing that during that particular time.
No, certainly equipment changes made some difference.
Problems that we faced initially, and to some extent the police still face it, we're not well equipped yet at all to deal with this.
Problem fades and interest in it fades and other items take budgetary preference.
Unfortunately, the police in dealing with crowds all too frequently find themselves either having to use a stick
or at the other extreme, deadly force, with nothing in between available to them.
So the first time we went out to the campus demonstrations at Michigan State University, it rolled up in a paddy wagon and it was stacked with shotguns with 12-oct buck in them.
Now that's absurd.
You're not going to use it.
You don't want to use that.
They weren't even distributed, by the way.
But even in terms of what you've got in your holster, really in that kind of situation, you'd rather not have in your revolver regular ammunition.
You'd be better off with something that was less deadly.
Later, by the way, the department did purchase burgeoning.
